document.docAuthor: Lu, Xiang-yi, Lin, Li, Liu, Jing, Liang, Li Li & Bian, Xun
document.docTitle: Anabropsis (Apteranabropsis) shii Lu, Lin, Liu, Liang & Bian, 2022, sp. nov.
document.masterDocTitle: Study of the Subfamily Anabropsinae (Orthoptera: Anostostomatidae) in China V Two new species of Anabropsis (Apteranabropsis) from Guangxi and phylogenetic analysis of the genus Anabropsis

mods:titleInfo.mods:title: Study of the Subfamily Anabropsinae (Orthoptera: Anostostomatidae) in China V Two new species of Anabropsis (Apteranabropsis) from Guangxi and phylogenetic analysis of the genus Anabropsis

subSubSection.paragraph: Description. Male. Body large, wingless. Fastigium verticis projecting forward, about three-fourths as wide as scape, dorsal surface with an indistinct longitudinal carina along the midline ( Figs. 7A , 9A ). Ocelli distinct, median ocellus oval, slightly longer than wide; lateral ocelli oval, suited on the lateral margins of fastigium verticis. Eyes projecting outwards. Apical segments of maxillary palpi longer than subapical ones, apices slightly swollen ( Fig. 7A ).

Coloration. Body brown. Face yellowish brown with blackish spots ( Figs. 7A , 9A, D ). Ocelli pale yellow. Dorsal surface of fastigium verticis, internal margins of antennal sockets, scapes, pedicelli and dorsum of head black, basal segments of flagellar with blackish rings ( Figs. 7B , 8A, C ). Disc of pronotum, mesonotum and metanotum black with yellowish spots at posterior margin ( Fig. 9B, E ); the lateral lobes of pronotum with large brown spot; dorsal surface of abdominal tergites brown with small yellow spots ( Figs. 7C , 8A , 9B, E ). Apical areas of femora and basal areas of tibiae with black spots ( Fig. 11G–H ). Abdominal sternites, basal half of femora and apical half of tibiae and tarsi yellowish brown.

Material examined.
Holotype : male (XZ258), Liuwanshan , Guangxi ,
August 31, 2021
, 22.558466° N , 109.856786° E , alt.
904.98 m
, coll. by Jing Liu and Xiangyi Lu
; Paratypes : 3 females , the other information as for holotype . Other specimens : 1 male and 1 female , the other information as holotype .

Discussion. The new species differs from
Anabropsis ( Apteranabropsis ) guangxiensis ( Bian & Shi, 2015 )
in: disc of pronotum without yellow longitudinal stripe along the midline ( Fig. 9B, E ), lateral lobes with large brown spot on each side ( Figs. 7B–C , 8A , 9B, E ); basal areas of prosternal lobes obviously widened and almost connected each other ( Figs. 7D , 8B ); the ventral margin of tip of male paraproctal processes forming straight, not hook-shaped in lateral view ( Fig. 7I ); the lateral margins of male subgenital plate contacted about basal third, the areas between the parallel carinae of ventral surface narrower, posterior margin almost straight ( Figs. 7H , 9C ).

caption.paragraph:
FIGURE 7.
Anabropsis ( Apteranabropsis ) shii
sp. nov. Male. A.
head in frontal view; B–D. head and pronotum: B. dorsal view, C. lateral view, D. ventral view; E–F. fore tibia: E. external view, F. internal view; G–H, J. apex of abdomen: G. lateral view, H. ventral view, J. dorsal view; I. paraproctal processes in lateral view; K–L. genitalia: K. dorsal view, L. ventral view.

FIGURE 8.
Anabropsis ( Apteranabropsis ) shii
sp. nov. Female. A–B.
head and pronotum: A. dorsal view, B. ventral view; C. subgenital plate in ventral view; D. apex of abdomen in lateral view; E–F. fore tibia: E. external view, F. internal view.

subSubSection.paragraph: Etymology. The new species is named after Professor Fuming Shi who makes great contribution to the Chinese Ensifera.

figureCitation.captionText: FIGURE 10. Anabropsis (Apteranabropsis) tonkinensis Rehn, 1906. Male. A–B. paraproctal processes in lateral view; C–D. genitalia: C. dorsal view, D. ventral view.
